results.title: Mathematical eye
results.creator_credit: Mike Cocker, Colin Nobbs, Adam Hart-Davis and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description: A series of 20 minute programs designed to help students understand mathematical concepts and relate them to the real world. The programs use computer graphics and animation to assist students in visualising problems and solutions.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mike Cocker, Colin Nobbs, Adam Hart-Davis and Yorkshire Television

results.title: Fun and games
results.creator_credit: Colin Nobbs, Adam Hart-Davis and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mathematical eye”.
This program consists entirely of short mathematical puzzles that students answer using problem-solving techniques. It also presents games that can be played in the classroom and a basic introduction to algebra.

results.title: Paper engineering
results.creator_credit: Colin Nobbs, Adam Hart-Davis and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mathematical eye”.
This program provides an introduction to geometry. It includes useful demonstrations showing how manufacturers use geometric principles to design packaging and how a variety of geometric shapes can be made by folding paper. The distinction is made between two and three dimensional shapes and the mathematical link between geometric shapes is explored.

results.title: Information technology
results.creator_credit: Colin Nobbs, Adam Hart-Davis and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mathematical eye”.
Provides the student with an introduction to common computer-related terms such as databases and fields, and considers capturing and storing data in a usable form. Explains how computers sort data to produce useful output and briefly examines computer aided design and manufacture.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin Nobbs, Adam Hart-Davis and Yorkshire Television

results.title: J'accuse
results.brief_description: J’accuse is a series designed to provoke and stimulate discussion as each episode critically examines the work of famous artists, writers, composers and filmmakers.

results.title: The Divine Mozart
results.creator_credit: Andrew Forrester, Jeremy Bugler, Channel Four and Fulmar
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “J’accuse”.
Nicholas Kenyon presents a critical look at the life and work of Mozart, exposing some of the myths that surround the famous composer. He rejects the notion of a saintly genius, who sacrificed himself for his art and died a pauper. When considered in the context of the historical period he lived in, Mozart emerges as a more “down to earth”, practical composer, who wrote music for money. The program includes comments from authorities in the music world and explores the reasons for Mozart’s popular appeal.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Andrew Forrester, Jeremy Bugler, Channel Four and Fulmar

results.title: Van Gogh
results.creator_credit: Gary Johnstone, Channel Four and Fulmar
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “J’accuse”.
Was Vincent Van Gogh a genius or a clumsy amateur? Art historian, Griselda Pollock presents a critical and provocative look at the life and work of this celebrated artist and examines some of the myths. Van Gogh is popularly perceived as a tragic but inspirational figure who was unappreciated during his life, but has since become one of the most famous artists of all time. Pollock tries to separate the facts from the legend and shows how powerful mass media and the art market have been in shaping our attitude towards art and artists.

results.title: Citizen Kane by Robert McKee
results.creator_credit: Gary Johnstone, Channel 4 and Fulman Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “J’accuse”.
Contrary to the traditional stance of acclaiming “Citizen Kane” as one of the greatest films of all time, Robert McKee, in this critical lecture on the film, believes that “Citizen Kane” has few of the attributes of great art. McKee believes that the style of the piece “jumps off the screen and applauds itself” while style and content fight each other. Welles’ is seen as a manipulator of the audience’s response, using cinematic techniques which saturate the film with visual metaphor. Importantly, McKee’s analysis sees a fundamental weakness in the plot and characterisation of the film, highighting the conflict Welles had with writer Herman Mankiewicz over the inclusion of the “Rosebud” plot as an example of this. McKee urges the viewer to see beyond the mythology of “Citizen Kane.”

results.title: Astronomy: an Open Learning unit
results.creator_credit: Michael Hollander, Monash University, Open University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: This astronomy series features the southern skies particularly the work being done in Australia by scientists and astronomers who are trying to unravel the secrets of the universe. These programs are part of an Open Learning unit and can be viewed in conjunction with the series entitled “Universe: the infinite frontier.”
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Hollander, Monash University, Open University and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: A Watch on the southern sky
results.creator_credit: Michael Hollander, ABC-TV (Australia), Open Learning Agency of Australia and Monash University
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Astronomy: an Open Learning unit”.
Provides a brief history of astronomy and a look at constellations. The program then focuses on how to map the sky and determine the location of celestial objects as well as looking at the differences between stars in terms of magnitude, colour and position. Examines the Moon and its cycles, and the location of planets in the night sky.
